newsitem.title: USA: Arkansas Sen. Dale Bumpers will not seek 5th term.
newsitem.headline: Arkansas Sen. Dale Bumpers will not seek 5th term.

text.p: - Sen. Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat who is a friend and political ally of President Clinton, said Saturday he would not seek election to a fifth term.

"I confess to an agonizing ambivalence about the decision and will probably suffer the torment of that ambivalence for the rest of my life. But intellectually it's right for me," Bumpers said, his voice cracking with emotion.
Bumpers said he was frustrated by his inability to influence legislation as a member of the minority party in the Senate and with bills being motivated by politics.
"Many bills are crafted to achieve maximum political benefit and little else," he complained.
Clinton said Saturday he had talked to Bumpers "several times" about his decision.
"I'm personally disappointed, but I understand," Clinton told reporters in San Diego.
In a written statement, the president praised Bumpers and said he would be missed.
"I have known and admired Dale Bumpers for over 25 years. He was a great governor and he has been a great senator for the people of our native state and the entire nation," he said.
"We will miss his courage to stand against the tide, his vision and his eloquence. Hillary and I wish him and Betty all the best. We will miss him. So will the Senate. So will America," Clinton said.
Bumpers was a strong favourite to win re-election despite its drift toward Republican candidates in recent years.

Immediate speculation regarding potential candidates for his Senate seat centred on Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican who unsuccessfully challenged Bumpers in 1992, and state Sen. Fay Boozman, another Republican.
Potential Democratic candidates include Arkansas Attorney General Winston Bryant and state Sen. Mike Beebe.

Bumpers was a political unknown in 1970 when he unseated Republican Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller. Four years later he defeated veteran Sen. J. William Fulbright in a Democratic primary and easily won election to the first of his four terms in the Senate.

Bumpers is regarded as a liberal in an increasingly conservative South. He consistently voted in favour of abortion rights and last month opposed legislation to prohibit partial birth abortions. He has also spoken against a constitutional amendment to make burning the U.S. flag illegal.

But Bumpers is considered a fiscal conservative. He frequently opposed large government spending programmes while criticising tax cuts he says will mainly benefit the wealthy. He has long opposed an amendment to balance the budget.
Sen. Bob Kerrey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, paid tribute to Bumpers as "a champion for America's working families."

"Dale Bumpers has served as a fearless leader of the Democratic Party in times of peril and in times of triumph," Kerrey said. "He reminds us that we are elected to uplift the family by protecting jobs, keeping streets safe, giving our kids a quality education and providing affordable health care."
Kerrey said he fully expected the seat vacated by Bumpers to remain in the Democratic column.
